support.p: Three folio sheets of paper with correspondence on recto and verso 1-6. The address is written perpendicular to last comments on page 6. The pages are folded in half and thirds twice more and were sealed for posting. This letter is glued into a scrapbook. The address leaf bears the remnants of a red circular wax seal, and an illegible black stamped Reading mileage stamp. The address appears to be written in another hand. READING

condition.p: Mitford notes that these pages are "soiled" because they were previously used to protect a MSS. Page 5 has a pieces torn out along the right border--probably due to opening the letter.Page 6 appears to have been repaired.

handNotes.handNote: Red or thick red pencil. Probably a different hand from Mitford's drawning a diagonal line (top left to bottom right) across pages 1-5
Someone wrote "3]" on the first page of the letter above "William" near the upuper left of the page.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded

opener.salute: To Sir W. ElfordPray write very soon indeed--Don't expect another letter till you have.--GodblessGod bless you my dear friend!

div.p: They are all gone to bed, my dear Sir William, & I have not a sheet of paper comeatablecome-at-able but one which has already done hard duty in keeping clean some M.S.S. so you have only your choice of the soiled paper or no letter to nighttonight--Which do you choose? Eh? I rather think the unclean paper--so I write. I began to think that you & I were trying as for a wager which should be silent longest & that you had taken one of the oaths by stg & that you wot of not to write first--& I was--(only that I would not tell the dear man so for the world for fear he should take it as a hint never to write in a fair honest battledore & shuttle-cockshuttlecock way again) I was actually meditating a second letter when your'syours arrived. Very delightful it is that long expected letter-- quite full of your charming vein. Yes by all manner of means put in the dog it is exactly what I wonder He the great unknown! did not put in himself--for he is a dear lover of the faithful race & generally foists in some dog or other wherever it is possible. Vide letters to Mr. Heber Esqre lending to prove Walter Scott (Sir Walter--I beg pardon of his Baronets ) the Author of Waverlty--which letters as you are a mightly Scotch hooeller I recommend to your perusal--They seem to me quite unanserable. Pray have you read Valerius yet? & don't you think there is a touch of his pen there? You will like it I promise you--for I did in spite of a strong predisposition to dislike the Romans who always seemed to me a sad sensual heartless race whose best virtues have a prodigious resemblance to crimes. Your

picture (Pray my dear friend invent for me a nack of getting back to a subject when one has unluckily strayed) your picture must with your fine taste & execution be charming--I have always had a preference for close, shut inshut-in scenes, both in a landscape & in nature, & prefer the end of a woody lane with a rustic bridge over a little stream, or a bit of an old cottage or farm House with a porch & a vine & clustered chimneys peeping out amongst trees to any prospect that I ever saw in my life. I dare say that this taste of mine is as wrong as I confess it to be ignoble--for I never met with any one who agreed with me in my opinion. But your picture will be quite poetry. I hope you will send it to Somerset House. Talking of pictures (this is not a jerk) we were a little astonished in common with all his friends, for he had kept it a profound level at Mr. Haydon's marriage. It is entirely a love match & I hope & trust that it will make him as happy as he deserves to be all his life long. He speaks of her (for I have heard from him several times) as still more amiable than beautiful, & as it has been a long acquaintance & not a very short courtship there is every reason to believe that he is right. She is in Devonshire just now to put the final close to some matters of business & he is gone to Scotland to put up his picture. I had a letter from him to daytoday dated Edinburgh-- the says that Allan(whom Dr. Peter Morris>, Alias John Lockhart, landed so incredibly) is very much improved indeed & will be an honourhonor to Scotland. He has just finished--no not quite finished is about--a picture which Mr. Haydon praises exceedingly. It is called the broken fiddle--an old wooden legged sailor has just broken his fiddle over the pate of a young dog who had been playing him some mischievous trick,--the boy's Grandam is clenching her fist at him & the sailor totally disregarding the old woman's scolding is enjoying the pain

of the unlucky lad. Pray do you know if Mr. Haydon's family were aware of his marriage? & if they approved it? Is his Father living? His Mother I know is not--for he often speaks of her with great regret & affection. He says that Mrs. H was married by her friends when very young to her first husband--whom he describes as no person pretty much as you do Pray can you give me any news of my dear friend Mrs. Dickinson? She is somewhere about your Devonshire Coast-- three months ago she disappeared from these parts & for six whole weeks I thought I had lost her--then she came to life again in two letters dated month in which she spoke in such raptures of Devonshire & the sea that she declared she did not think she could ever resign herself to living inland again. Since these letters I have lost her once more & only that I know the Devonshire air has sometimes an anti-epistolary effect upon my best & dearest & cleverest friends. I should really be afraid that some sea God had taken her at her word & whisked her off to live with the mermaids & those worthy people. I hope this soggy November will drive her home--Or at least drive her to letter writing--she sometimes lends a little bit of journalizing which is charming--quite as metrically & sweetly written as if it were all make believemake-believe & got up for the Magazines. This will seem to you an odd compliment--but it is so--the really natural in writing is an exquisitly labouredlabored & difficult thing--the very perfection of art-- which is the reason why my letters in spite of a little & sprig & things are I am afraid altogether good for nothing. They are at present in status quo--for I have been engaged in the tormenting business of altering & re-altering my poor Play. You cannot--unless you write a Tragedy yourself with five different catastrophes as I have done-- form the slighest notion what a miserable business

alteration is. At present Mr. Macready has my Tragedy with four different conclusions (that is to say four fifth acts) of which he is to take his choice! He enters into it heart & soul & is a most warm & zealous friend, but I am still afraid that it will be replaced by the manager--all is intrigue behind the curtain--& to add to my misfortunes Lord Byron has written a Tragedy on the same subject--which will of course be as bold & daring as mine is feeble & womanish.

Monday. I have got a frank for the day & having unluckily been hindered by those Gadflies morning visitors must finish at the gallop. Apropos to franks I have not been that accomplished Franker Mr. Palmer or his charming wife since last September twelvemonth!--We have been very gay at Reading with our perennial Theatricals--Dr. Valpy'sGreek Play. There is nothing so charming as that classical amusement (by the way the Doctor always makes me write the official puff account & I have been hunting more minutes than I ought to have spared from my letter to find a Reading paper toshewshow you what a famous theatrical critic I am--but I can't find it so you must belive my own puff of my puffing)--Nothing so charming as the Greek Play, with its beautiful accuracy of costume, every fold copied after some antique statue, its fine groupoing & the delicious sound of that magnificient language. The Play this year was Orestes of Euripides of which the opening scene is perhaps one of the finest & truest exhibitions of nature that has ever been given by any Poet in any language. The Greek Play was enchanting--but every pleasure has its alloy, & Dr. Valpy against all prayer & all warning was determined to make us pay pay for our delight by inflicting on us after the Orestes the three last acts of King John as altered

from Shakespeare by himself. Fancy the worst facts of Shakespeare's worst play with the most iniquitous alterations ever devised by schoolmaster acted by a rabble of boys of all ages & sizes--all bad. Some thick & shaped like pincushions--others pointed & angular & sharp limbed as it were, like scissarsscissors--the Dauphin a little round short fellow not taller than a thimble & King Philip a limber lad, tall & bent in the middle like a broken thread paperthread-paper! Oh that King John! I shan't recover it these two years.--Ever since the Greek Play I have been trying as well as I can in French & English & Italian translations to get at the Greek Dramatists, & am so in love with Aeschylus & Sophocles (Euripides though very fine rather in a lower style--more pathetic than sublime) that I can really hardly think or talk of any thinganything else. Sophocles in particular--& of all SophoclesPhiloctetes exceeds all that I have ever seen before. There never was & never will be any thinganything like the Greek Dramatists. The words are broken--the English romantic Drama is not more different from them in form than the French in spirit. The English Translations of Sophocles are abominable--I find that I get at him best from a literal version in French prose--& I have half a mind to do the Philoctetes into English from that source--declaring of course in the Preface that I know nothing at all of Greek & took it from the Abbe >-- but this I have not resolved upon.
GodblessGod bless you my dear friend--I hope to hear a better account of both your --Kindest regards from all--Everyour'sEver yours
We have mentioned your Residence to let wherever we thought it probable to produce a tenant--but in vain.--Once more goodbye!

Reading November twenty five
Sr Wm Elfrod Bart
Bickham
J.B. MonckPlymouth

place.note: A hamlet included in the parish of Timberscombe, Somerset, England.
City located on the south coast of Devon, England, 190 miles south-west of London.

person.note: The Dauphin is the son of the King of France in Shakespeare'sHenry V.
King Philip is the King of France in Shakespeare'sKing John
Dr. Peter Morris is a fictional character in John Gibson Lockhart's 1819 novel, Peter's Letters to his Kinfolk.

Allan was a painter. In 1838 he was appointed president of the Royal Scottish Academy. 1841 became the queen's limner in Scotland and was knighted (ODNB). MRM mentions his painting Broken Fiddle in her letter to Elford, 1821-11-21
Lockhart was a writer and literary editor. His best known work is his biography of Sir Walter Scot (7 vols.,1837-8; 2nd edn, rev., 10 vols., 1839; abridged and rev., 2 vols., 1848)(ODNB).
Mr. Haydon was the father of painter Benjamin Robert Haydon and was a printer, publisher, and bookseller in Devon (ODNB).
Sarah Haydon was the mother of painter Benjamin Robert Haydon (ODNB).
